scientificName: Capsicum annuum, Capsicum frutescens, et al.
description: The fruit of plants from the genus Capsicum which are members of the nightshade family, Solanaceae. Chilies are widely used as a spice to add pungent 'heat' to dishes. Colors range from green (unripe) to red, yellow, orange, or purple (ripe).
healthBenefits: Rich in Vitamin C, a powerful antioxidant.
Contain capsaicin, the compound responsible for their pungency, which has anti-inflammatory properties and may boost metabolism.
May have pain-relieving effects (capsaicin is used in topical creams).

potentialAllergies.name: Capsaicin Sensitivity
potentialAllergies.details: Can cause burning sensation in the mouth, stomach upset, or heartburn in sensitive individuals. Handling can irritate skin (wear gloves).

potentialAllergies.name: Nightshade Sensitivity
potentialAllergies.details: Some individuals may be sensitive to nightshades.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Planting: Warm-season crop. Start seeds indoors 8-10 weeks before last frost or buy transplants.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter. pH 6.0-6.8. Full sun.
3. Spacing: Space plants 12-18 inches apart.
4. Watering: Consistent watering, especially during flowering and fruiting. Avoid waterlogging.
5. Harvesting: Harvest when fruits reach desired size and color. Green chilies are unripe; many turn red, orange, or yellow when fully ripe. Heat often increases with ripeness.
growthDuration: 60-100+ days from transplanting to first harvest, depending on variety.
sustainabilityTips: Store fresh chilies in the refrigerator for 1-2 weeks. Dried chilies can be stored for months.
Wear gloves when handling very hot chilies to avoid skin irritation.
Chilies can be dried, pickled, or frozen for preservation.
carbonFootprintInfo: Generally low for fresh chilies (0.4-0.8 kg CO2e/kg). Dried and processed forms (powders, sauces) will have variations.

staticRecipes.name: Simple Chili Garlic Sauce
staticRecipes.description: A versatile and spicy sauce, great as a condiment or cooking ingredient.
ingredients: 10-15 fresh red chilies (e.g., Thai chilies or similar), stemmed
2 tbsp water (or more for desired consistency)
steps: Combine all ingredients (chilies, garlic, vinegar, sugar, salt, water) in a blender or food processor.
Blend until mostly smooth, or to desired texture (some prefer it slightly chunky). Add more water if too thick.
Taste and adjust seasoning (sugar, salt, vinegar) if needed.
Transfer to a clean jar and store in the refrigerator. It will keep for several weeks.

staticRecipes.name: Stuffed Green Chilies (Mirchi Bajji/Pakora style filling)
staticRecipes.description: Large green chilies stuffed with a savory filling, often battered and fried (filling recipe only).
ingredients: 6-8 large, mildly hot green chilies (e.g., Anaheim, Poblano, or Indian Bajji Mirchi)

For stuffing: 1/2 cup gram flour (besan), 1/4 tsp turmeric powder, 1/2 tsp cumin powder, 1/2 tsp coriander powder, 1/4 tsp amchur (dry mango powder), pinch of asafoetida (hing), salt to taste, 2-3 tbsp water to make a thick paste
steps: Wash chilies. Make a lengthwise slit on one side of each chili, keeping the stem intact. Carefully remove seeds if you want to reduce heat.
Stuffing: In a bowl, mix gram flour, turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, amchur, asafoetida, and salt. Add water gradually to form a very thick, spreadable paste.
Carefully stuff this paste into each slit chili.
These stuffed chilies can then be shallow fried, baked, or dipped in a separate pakora batter and deep-fried according to various recipes for Mirchi Bajji or Stuffed Peppers.

staticRecipes.name: Homemade Red Chili Flakes
staticRecipes.description: Make your own dried red chili flakes for a fresh, potent spice.
ingredients: A handful of dried red chilies (e.g., Cayenne, Arbol, or any hot variety)
steps: Ensure chilies are completely dry and brittle.
Remove stems. If you want milder flakes, you can slit the chilies and shake out some or all of the seeds.
Wear gloves if handling very hot chilies.
Break the dried chilies into smaller pieces by hand or roughly chop them.
Place the chili pieces in a spice grinder, coffee grinder (dedicated to spices), or a mortar and pestle.
Pulse or grind briefly until they are crushed into flakes of desired size. Be careful not to over-grind into a fine powder unless intended.
Store in an airtight container in a cool, dark place. Use to add heat to pizzas, pastas, stir-fries, etc.
